CDlgOptionText.cpp

00001 /*
00002  * CDlgOptionText.cpp
00003  *
00004  *  Created on: 19.08.2009
00005  *      Author: gerstrong
00006  */
00007 
00008 #include "CDlgOptionText.h"
00009 
00010 #include "../graphics/CGfxEngine.h"
00011 
00012 /**
00013  * \brief   Constructor of the class. It represents a text which can be selected in the menu.
00014  *    As it is an option text, it is there all the time, it can be selected, truncated, and even
00015  *    have another fontmap, like the extra tile ones which can be assigned at any time. Those
00016  *    are used for the sliders as an example...
00017  *
00018  * \param text     The text that will be written in that option item
00019  * \param delimtier   Usually the width-2 of the menu box, as this will
00020  *       automatically truncate the text making it fit into the box
00021  * \param fontmapID This is the ID to the fontmap which can be changed, so for example
00022  *       the extra tiles in vorticons engine (for sliders) can be used
00023  *
00024  */
00025 CDlgOptionText::CDlgOptionText(const std::string &text, unsigned int delimit, Uint8 fontmapID)
00026 {
00027  setText(text, delimit);
00028  m_FontMapID = fontmapID;
00029 }
00030 
00031 /**
00032  * \brief   technically it does the same as the contructor, because the constructor calls that function.
00033  *    if you call it anyway, it will apply the changes you are putting into...
00034  *
00035  * \param text     The text that will be written in that option item
00036  * \param delimtier   Usually the width-2 of the menu box, as this will
00037  *       automatically truncate the text making it fit into the box
00038  * \param fontmapID This is the ID to the fontmap which can be changed, so for example
00039  *       the extra tiles in vorticons engine (for sliders) can be used
00040  */
00041 void CDlgOptionText::setText(const std::string &text, unsigned int delimit) {
00042  m_text = text;
00043  
00044  if(m_text.size() > delimit )
00045  {
00046   m_text.erase(delimit-3);
00047   m_text += "...";
00048  }
00049 }
00050 
00051 /**
00052  * \brief   This normally is part of a routine cycle and draws the text on the SDL-Surface
00053  *
00054  * \param Textsurface Pointer to the SDL-Surface where Text has to be drawn.
00055  *       Normally it's a blit surface
00056  * \param x     X-Coordinate where to draw the text
00057  * \param y     Y-Coordinate where to draw the text
00058  *       automatically truncate the text making it fit into the box
00059  * \param highlight The vorticon engine especially has the black text and the red-grayed-one
00060  *       in the same fontmap. To enable that red-grayed text, just put this parameter
00061  *       to true. (normally false)
00062  * \param colour  Not given it will put it into black. Since the new GFX-Engine Update you can
00063  *       use any text colour you want, the fontmap will be tinted temporary to get it printed
00064  *       using the colour of your wish. Caution: Changing the colour too many times in a cycle
00065  *       may cause the system to slow down. If you want to write something where every letter has
00066  *       a different colour, please don't use this...
00067  */
00068 void CDlgOptionText::draw(SDL_Surface *Textsurface, Uint16 x, Uint16 y, bool highlight, Uint32 colour)
00069 {
00070  CFont &Font = g_pGfxEngine->getFont(m_FontMapID);
00071 
00072  Font.setFGColour(Textsurface->format, colour);
00073 
00074  Font.drawFont(Textsurface, m_text, x, y, highlight);
00075 }
00076 
00077 CDlgOptionText::~CDlgOptionText()
00078 {}
